bars.title: Line Chef
bars.subtitle: Full-time
bars.summary: For the most part, I was a Yakitori cook and responsible for the daily functioning of the section (hot kitchen).

bars.title: IT Support
bars.subtitle: Part-time
bars.summary: This was a helpdesk position where I answered to IT issues, and developed small tools.

bars.title: Developer
bars.subtitle: Part-time
bars.summary: As part of the Digital Performance team, I developed many tools to streamline and automate diverse workflows and pipelines. In addition, I developed a webapp to unify and simplify the team's daily tasks.

bars.title: Consultant
bars.subtitle: Full-time
bars.summary: The last role at BC, where I help the team with product development tasks and further improve their internal documentation.

bars.title: Cyber Security Consultant
bars.subtitle: Full-time
bars.summary: For a brief but intense time, I help organisations to improve their cyber security.

bars.title: Contributor
bars.subtitle: Full-time
bars.summary: This was a paid position as a GSOC 2022 contributor in collaboration with the Honeynet project to work on the RIoTPot honeypot. I enhanced the honeypot with a number of features, including device profiles and a proxy to route connections to other honeypots through RIoTPot.

bars.title: BSc in IT Communication and new Media (ITCOM)
bars.subtitle: Full-time
bars.summary: The bachelor tackles basic concepts regarding application development, cyber security, communication protocols, Internet of Things (IoT), and computer hardware.

bars.title: MSc in Cyber Security
bars.subtitle: Full-time
bars.summary: For two years, I learned advanced topics in cyber security following the problem-based learning model, where each semester included a range of group projects with topics such as attack and defense, and cyber deception. The most notable projects I worked on were the RIoTPot honeypot, and our own crawler for darkweb marketplaces named Midnight Sea.

bars.title: PhD student
bars.subtitle: Full-time
bars.summary: The main topic of my PhD is to investigate Digital Ghost Ships (DGS). DGS are Internet facing devices with obselete cyber security (e.g., weak passwords and unpatched systems).
